content:
Can we take the numerators of a finite set of fractions (as a finset)?
I only found docs#IsLocalizedModule.finsetIntegerMultiple.
Any help or clarification would be appreciated!
E.g., are you talking about Rat or something more general?
Sorry for missing some details. I want to use it for a set of LocalizedModule or IsLocalizedModule.
If you have a function for the numerator, then you can use Finset.image.

Do you mean something like this?

import Mathlib

variable {R : Type*} [CommSemiring R] (S : Submonoid R)
variable {M M' : Type*} [AddCommMonoid M] [AddCommMonoid M']
variable [Module R M] [Module R M'] [DecidableEq M] (f : M →ₗ[R] M') [IsLocalizedModule S f]

noncomputable def getNumerator (x : M') : M :=
  (Classical.choose (IsLocalizedModule.surj S f x)).1

noncomputable def finsetNumerator (s : Finset M') : Finset M := Finset.image (getNumerator S f) s
If mathlib doesn’t have a better definition, I’ll just use this one.
Thank you all for your help — now I’ve learned how to use Finset.image.
It's not clear to me that getNumerator picks a particularly canonical numerator
IN particular, you might find that {1/2, 2/5} has numerators {2} if 1/2 ends up being treated as 2/4.
Well, that’s a problem. Let me think about how to choose the canonical numerator...

Mathematically you're not going to have a canonical numerator, even in the integral domain case. Having a canonical numerator is the same as having a canonical denominator in the integral domain case when M=R, and what you have instead is the ideal of denominators, which has no reason to be principal, so you don't even have a canonical numerator up to units in this generality.
Kevin, am I right in thinking this somehow featured in some Lean slides of yours long ago? I was expecting you to have something to say here :)

I don't know about slides, but mathematically the issue is that if RRR is an integral domain with field of fractions KKK, and if x∈Kx\in Kx∈K then you can consider I:={d∈R∣dx∈R}I:=\{d\in R\mid dx\in R\}I:={d∈R∣dx∈R} and this is easily checked to be an ideal of RRR, but if RRR is not a PID then you can say very little about it, let alone choose a canonical element of it.

Example: if R=Z[−5]={a+b−5∣a,b∈Z}R=\Z[\sqrt{-5}]=\{a+b\sqrt{-5}\mid a,b\in\Z\}R=Z[−5​]={a+b−5​∣a,b∈Z} and x=1+−52x=\frac{1+\sqrt{-5}}{2}x=21+−5​​ then III contains 222 and 1−−51-\sqrt{-5}1−−5​ so it's the nonprincipal ideal whose square is 2 and which generates the (nontrivial) class group of RRR.

In more elementary terms, x=1+−52=31−−5x=\frac{1+\sqrt{-5}}{2}=\frac{3}{1-\sqrt{-5}}x=21+−5​​=1−−5​3​ and both these fractions are in "lowest terms" (in the sense that there are no common factors than you can cancel other than ±1\pm1±1) but their numerators don't even differ by a unit.

What's going on here is that 6=2×3=(1+−5)(1−−5)6=2\times 3=(1+\sqrt{-5})(1-\sqrt{-5})6=2×3=(1+−5​)(1−−5​) is two distinct factorizations of 666 into irreducibles (the ring is an integral domain but not a UFD).

Historically it was known since Euclid that the greatest common divisor of two integers was a linear combination of the integers (if the gcd of aaa and bbb is ddd then there are integers $$\lambda$4 anad μ\muμ such that d=λa+μbd=\lambda a+\mu bd=λa+μb), so to try and "fix" this factorization of 6 you need some kind of gcd of 2 and 1+−51+\sqrt{-5}1+−5​, and you can start looking for it by looking at the linear combinations 2λ+(1+−5)μ)2\lambda +(1+\sqrt{-5})\mu)2λ+(1+−5​)μ) where λ,μ∈Z[−5]=:R\lambda,\mu\in\Z[\sqrt{-5}]=:Rλ,μ∈Z[−5​]=:R (because that worked for Z\ZZ) and you're not sure which one to choose, so you let III be the set of all of them, and then you realise that if JJJ is the analogous set for 3,1+−53,1+\sqrt{-5}3,1+−5​ and KKK for 3,1−−53,1-\sqrt{-5}3,1−−5​ then I2=2RI^2=2RI2=2R and JK=3RJK=3RJK=3R and IJ=(1+−5)RIJ=(1+\sqrt{-5})RIJ=(1+−5​)R so now 6R=I2JK6R=I^2JK6R=I2JK and this factorization is unique, so these sets are behaving better than numbers, so they're like "ideal numbers" because things are factorizing uniquely again. Historically a lot of the basics of ring theory like ideals were invented in the mid-1800s by number theorists through the study of concrete subsets of the complexes, before abstract algebra was discovered around 1900.
